title: Nipah Virus Vaccine (PHV02)
author: Staff
description: Nipah virus vaccine candidate PHV02 is a novel recombinant vaccine that uses a modified rabies virus vector and incorporates a gene from the Nipah virus
cleaned_text: is a live, attenuated, recombinant vesicular stomatitis virus (rVSV) vector vaccine candidate that expresses the glycoprotein of the Nipah virus (Bangladesh strain) and the Ebola virus glycoprotein, which is required for receptor-mediated viral entry. The rVSV-Nipah vaccine was developed by the Laboratory of [Dr. Heinz Feldmann](https://www.niaid.nih.gov/research/heinz-feldmann-md-phd) within the Laboratory of Virology, Division of Intramural Research, National Institute of Allergy and Infectious Diseases ( [NIAID](https://www.niaid.nih.gov/)) part of the U.S. NIH, and has been licensed to Public Health Vaccines by the NIAID. Public Health Vaccines (PHV) has been [developing](https://nipahvaccine.com/) the [rVSVG-EBOV GP/NiV G](https://www.phvaccines.com/PHV02.html) vaccine candidate in partnership with the Coalition for Epidemic Preparedness and Innovations ( [CEPI](https://cepi.net/news_cepi/cepi-awards-up-to-us43-6-million-to-public-health-vaccines-llc-for-development-of-a-single-dose-nipah-virus-vaccine-candidate/)) under an award of up to US$43.6 million that facilitates development through Phase 2 clinical trials, including supportive non-clinical and manufacturing activities. A [Phase 1](https://clinicaltrials.gov/ct2/show/NCT05178901) clinical study evaluating the rVSV-Nipah Virus Vaccine Candidate PHV02 in Healthy Adult Subjects was last updated on April 20, 2022. Nipah virus has caused outbreaks in [Bangladesh](https://www.sciencedirect.com/science/article/pii/S1201971220322451) since 2001 and occasionally in neighboring India, Singapore, and the Philippines. Public Health Vaccines, LLC. ( [PHV](https://www.phvaccines.com/index.html)), headquartered in Cambridge, Massachusetts, is a privately-held biotechnology company developing products to prevent and control emerging infectious diseases. The company initially focused on creating vaccines against the [Marburg virus](https://www.phvaccines.com/PHV01.html) and [Sudan ebolavirus](https://www.phvaccines.com/PHV03.html) utilizing the rVSV platform in collaboration with the Biomedical Advanced Research and Development Authority ( [BARDA](https://aspr.hhs.gov/AboutASPR/ProgramOffices/BARDA/Pages/default.aspx)). Nipah Virus Overview Nipah virus is a [paramyxovirus](https://www.who.int/news-room/fact-sheets/detail/nipah-virus) whose wildlife reservoir is the fruit bat (genus Pteropus). Characteristics of Nipah virus infection that increase the risk of engendering a global pandemic include the susceptibility of humans and the high rate of mutation, which is inherent in RNA viruses. Together, these characteristics could support the emergence of a human-adapted strain capable of spreading rapidly by infecting communities with high population density and global interconnectedness. Nipah Virus Vaccine (PHV02) Clinical Trials The [Phase is a randomized, double-blind, placebo-controlled, single-center, study designed to evaluate the safety, tolerability, and immunogenicity of three dose levels of PHV02 in 60 healthy adults in the U.S. Assuming favorable results, PHV plans to initiate a Phase 2 trial in 2022 in a disease-endemic region.
